trans-unit.source: When you run <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> in embedded mode or when you use the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> Network Server, you can enable or disable server-side user authentication. However, when you use the Network Server, the default security mechanism (<codeph>CLEAR_TEXT_PASSWORD_SECURITY</codeph>) requires that you supply both the user name and password.

seg-source.mrk: When you run <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> in embedded mode or when you use the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> Network Server, you can enable or disable server-side user authentication.
However, when you use the Network Server, the default security mechanism (<codeph>CLEAR_TEXT_PASSWORD_SECURITY</codeph>) requires that you supply both the user name and password.

target.mrk: When you run <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> in embedded mode or when you use the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> Network Server, you can enable or disable server-side user authentication.
However, when you use the Network Server, the default security mechanism (<codeph>CLEAR_TEXT_PASSWORD_SECURITY</codeph>) requires that you supply both the user name and password.

trans-unit.source: In addition to the default user name and password security mechanism, <codeph>org.apache.derby.jdbc.ClientDataSource.CLEAR_TEXT_PASSWORD_SECURITY</codeph>, <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> Network Server supports the following security properties:

seg-source.mrk: In addition to the default user name and password security mechanism, <codeph>org.apache.derby.jdbc.ClientDataSource.CLEAR_TEXT_PASSWORD_SECURITY</codeph>, <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> Network Server supports the following security properties:

target.mrk: In addition to the default user name and password security mechanism, <codeph>org.apache.derby.jdbc.ClientDataSource.CLEAR_TEXT_PASSWORD_SECURITY</codeph>, <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> Network Server supports the following security properties:

trans-unit.source: When you use this mechanism, you must specify only the <codeph>user</codeph> property. All other mechanisms require you to specify both the user name and the password.

seg-source.mrk: When you use this mechanism, you must specify only the <codeph>user</codeph> property.
All other mechanisms require you to specify both the user name and the password.

target.mrk: When you use this mechanism, you must specify only the <codeph>user</codeph> property.
All other mechanisms require you to specify both the user name and the password.

trans-unit.source: When you use this mechanism, both password and user id are encrypted.

seg-source.mrk: When you use this mechanism, both password and user id are encrypted.

target.mrk: When you use this mechanism, both password and user id are encrypted.

trans-unit.source: The user name that is specified upon connection is the default schema for the connection, if a schema with that name exists. See the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#pub/citdevelop"></ph> for more information on schema and user names.

seg-source.mrk: The user name that is specified upon connection is the default schema for the connection, if a schema with that name exists.
See the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#pub/citdevelop"></ph> for more information on schema and user names.

target.mrk: The user name that is specified upon connection is the default schema for the connection, if a schema with that name exists.
See the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#pub/citdevelop"></ph> for more information on schema and user names.

trans-unit.source: If you specify any other security mechanism, you will receive an exception.

seg-source.mrk: If you specify any other security mechanism, you will receive an exception.

target.mrk: If you specify any other security mechanism, you will receive an exception.

trans-unit.source: To change the default, you can specify another security mechanism either as a property or on the URL (using the <codeph>securityMechanism=value</codeph> attribute) when you make the connection. For details, see <xref href="cadminappsclientsecurity.dita#cadminappsclientsecurity"></xref> and "securityMechanism=value attribute" in the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#pub/citref"></ph>.

seg-source.mrk: To change the default, you can specify another security mechanism either as a property or on the URL (using the <codeph>securityMechanism=value</codeph> attribute) when you make the connection.
For details, see <xref href="cadminappsclientsecurity.dita#cadminappsclientsecurity"></xref> and "securityMechanism=value attribute" in the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#pub/citref"></ph>.

target.mrk: To change the default, you can specify another security mechanism either as a property or on the URL (using the <codeph>securityMechanism=value</codeph> attribute) when you make the connection.
For details, see <xref href="cadminappsclientsecurity.dita#cadminappsclientsecurity"></xref> and "securityMechanism=value attribute" in the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#pub/citref"></ph>.

trans-unit.source: Whether the security mechanism you specify for the client actually takes effect depends upon the setting of the <codeph>derby.drda.securityMechanism</codeph> property for the Network Server. If the <codeph>derby.drda.securityMechanism</codeph> property is set, the Network Server accepts only connections that use the security mechanism specified by the property setting. If the <codeph>derby.drda.securityMechanism</codeph> property is not set, clients can use any valid security mechanism. For details, see <xref href="radmindrdasecmechanism.dita#radmindrdasecmechanism"></xref>.

seg-source.mrk: Whether the security mechanism you specify for the client actually takes effect depends upon the setting of the <codeph>derby.drda.securityMechanism</codeph> property for the Network Server.
If the <codeph>derby.drda.securityMechanism</codeph> property is set, the Network Server accepts only connections that use the security mechanism specified by the property setting.
If the <codeph>derby.drda.securityMechanism</codeph> property is not set, clients can use any valid security mechanism.

target.mrk: Whether the security mechanism you specify for the client actually takes effect depends upon the setting of the <codeph>derby.drda.securityMechanism</codeph> property for the Network Server.
If the <codeph>derby.drda.securityMechanism</codeph> property is set, the Network Server accepts only connections that use the security mechanism specified by the property setting.
If the <codeph>derby.drda.securityMechanism</codeph> property is not set, clients can use any valid security mechanism.
